When Bardina Degei cooks dinner , she uses no stove .
It even rarely uses a pot .

In her wooden house in Enarotali , the capital of the Paniai regime in the troubled Indonesian province of Papua , the housewife usually puts a sweet potato - locally called " nota " - directly into the fireplace .
After half an hour , the carved knell is taken and swallowed with eager , unwashed hands .
Degei sits on the clay floor - she has no furniture - where she also performs her daily work , for example washing clothes with bleak water from the nearby swamp .
A bucket in a roofless room serves as a latrine .
As the youngest of her husband 's four wives , no fields were assigned to her .
Polygamy is common here .
Of course , late work can be dangerous : most villagers are unemployed , and many drink hard , and there are soldiers here .
Nobody dares to walk around in the village after 5 p.m.  , she says .

It is a rare insight into daily life in the highlands of Papua , a former Dutch colony , which was inaugurated in 1969 following a controversial referendum in Indonesia , when only 1,026 elders should vote through a public hike before the occupying forces .

An existing movement that stirred up for independence against Dutch rule quickly turned against the government of Jakarta , which maintains control of the region and excludes foreign journalists or legal observers .
In 2003 , the province was officially divided into Papua and West Papua , with the independent part of Papua New Guinea including the eastern part of the island .
Enarotali is as remote as it is .
There is no public transport .
The city with about 19,000 inhabitants consists of wooden houses surrounded by bamboo fences , and of sheet metal roofs converted by rust into various yellow brown tones .
Only very few Indonesians have made their journey here , let alone journalists , and virtually no foreigners .
Before Christian missionaries arrived , Mee Pago Papuans revered a god called Uga Tamee .
There have also been other changes .
We were not used to wearing this clothing ,  says Degei and points to her lively , handwoven turban , her dark shirt and her bright rock .
In the past we had only leaves on our bodies .
Papua is Indonesia ’ s poorest province , where 28 % of people live below the poverty line and have some of the worst child mortality and literacy rates in Asia .
But it is also Indonesia ’ s gold land .

The largest and most profitable gold mine in the world , Grasberg , owned by the Freeport McMoran from Phoenix , is only 60 miles from Paniai , a highland province in the size of New Jersey with 153,000 inhabitants .
